title: The wonders of hair
intro: The hair follicle apparently knows some tricks that the other organs don’t know, says Ralf Paus, hair loss researcher. Neil and Tim talk about the wonders of hair and teach you six items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: How many hair follicles does the human body have today? Is it …
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: scary often in an exciting way
the organ that produces a hair underneath the skin
having little or no hair on your head

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, where today we introduce a hair-raising topic and six items of vocabulary.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I’m Tim… So what’s hair-raising about today’s topic, Neil? Hair-raising means scary but also exciting!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We’re talking about hair – which may be exciting for some, but definitely won’t be scary.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Hair-raising is a real thing, though, isn’t it? Our hairs do rise!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes – Tim, they do. We get goose bumps when we’re cold, scared, or excited.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: But other mammals do it better than us – Cats fluff up when they see other cats they don’t like.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s true – We can’t fluff up because we don’t have enough body hair.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I suppose we used to be as hairy as gorillas – if you go back a million years or so.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Do you know why we lost so much hair, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Isn’t it because it allowed us to sweat more easily? This meant we didn’t get so hot and tired – we could run faster and for longer – and catch more animals to eat! Neil That sounds like a good theory. But do you have a theory on how many hair follicles the human body has today?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: What’s a hair follicle?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A hair follicle is the organ that produces a hair underneath the skin. Now answer the question, Tim. How many hair follicles does the human body have today? Is it … a) 500,000, b) 5 million or c) 50 million?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: 50 million sounds about right.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Did you know that men have more than women, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: No, I didn’t – but it makes sense since men are usually hairier than women.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: On their faces – but not necessarily on their heads!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Are you referring to the fact that men of a certain age can be follically challenged?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If you’re follically challenged it means you’re losing your hair! Having little or no hair is called baldness . And if you’ve reached a certain age it means you aren’t young any more!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Why is our hair so important to us, Neil? When we aren’t worrying about going bald, we’re busy shaving, waxing, plucking, and trimming the stuff. When I say ‘we’ of course I’m referring to people in general. Not myself…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, a good head of hair indicates health and youth. And hair on your face – facial hair – shows when boys have reached manhood.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: On the other hand, going grey or losing your hair shows you’re getting older. Neil Hair today, gone tomorrow?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Bad joke, Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sorry! It’s true that hair on your head shows signs of aging – but this isn’t true of all human hair. Let’s listen to Ralf Paus, a leading hair loss researcher, talking about this. INSERT Ralf Paus, hair loss researcher The eyebrows get stronger usually in aging men, the hairs in your nose and in your ears get stronger – and what a miracle of nature that an organ – when the entire body is aging actually grows stronger. So we may even be able to learn from hair follicles how not to age.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Hmm. I’m not sure I would swap a good head of hair for thick eyebrows and nose hair. How about you, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I agree! But let’s hear more from Ralf Paus about why some hair gets stronger as you get older.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Ralf Paus, hair loss researcher The hair follicle apparently knows some tricks that the other organs don’t know. So it’s continuously regenerating itself. It goes through a so-called hair cycle and part of that we know pretty well – and that is, these stem cells that it uses to regenerate cells.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: So a hair follicle can regenerate cells – or grow new cells to replace old or damaged ones. But if that’s only true for eyebrows, nose and ear hair, I am not that impressed! I want hairs on my head to be able to regenerate!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The important thing here is that these cells in the hair follicle may help scientists discover a way to stop other organs of the body aging… OK, I’m now going to reveal how many hair follicles on average we have on our bodies. The answer is… 5 million.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Oh. So not 50 million then.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Don’t worry, Tim! It was a tricky question! Now let’s go over the words we learned today.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: ‘Hair-raising’ means scary often in an exciting way. For example, “That ride on the rollercoaster was a hair-raising experience!”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Next is ‘hair follicle’ – the organ that produces a hair underneath the skin.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “Scientists believe that stress can affect hair follicles.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A number of things can affect hair follicles actually – age, disease, diet…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: OK – but we haven’t got all day, Neil. So let’s move on to the next item. ‘Baldness’ – which means having little or no hair on your head.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “My grandfather is bald and he always wears a hat to cover his baldness.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Nice example. Is your grandpa actually bald, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No – he has a fine head of hair. Now, if you are a certain age, it means you are no longer young. For example…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “All the people at the party were of a certain age…”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How many of them had facial hair, Tim? That’s our next word, and ‘facial’ means to do with the face.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “None of the people at the party had facial hair.” There’s your answer!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s unusual, Tim. Lots of men have beards these days. OK – our final word for today is ‘regenerate’ which means to grow again. You can talk about regenerating a range of things, for example…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “The council has plans to regenerate this part of the city.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “Regeneration of parts of the city is in progress.” – ‘regeneration’ is the noun.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, it’s time to go now. But if today’s show gave you goosebumps please let us know by visiting our Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages and telling us about it!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Bye-bye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!
